On Truth
What is Truth? Defining truth is fundamental to understanding it; however, there are several definitions of truth. In each definition, "truth" just means consistency against some standards. As a truth's standards become more well-defined, they coalesce into complex conceptual-frameworks.1 These conceptual-frameworks define exactly how truth-value is determined from a truth's standards. Each standard of truth is a basis for truth-value.2 As such, choosing well-defined standards is cucial to evaluating the truth-value of a statement. I would like to call attention to four standards: coherence, correspondence, consensus, and authority.3
Standards of Truth Definition
Coherence Requirement for consistency within a set of propositions.
Correspondence Requirement for consistency with empirical observations.
Consensus Requirement for consistency between of individuals.
Authority Requirement for consistency with particular individuals.

It is valuable to understand each of these common standards before exploring different truths.
Relative Truths Mathematical Truth (Standard: Coherence) Scientific Truth (Standards: Coherence and Correspondence) Social Truth (Standards: Consensus and Authority)
The conceptual framework for truth is categorical with each category arising from combinations of different standards of truth.
Some standards of truth are derived from self-evident and fundamental concepts: nothingness,1 existence,2 distinction, and experience. Nothingness and existence are not directly relevant, but epistemicly precede distinction. Distinction refers to the ability define things, and experience refers to the immutable nature of physical reality. These are derived into two standards of truth: coherence and correspondence. Coherence asserts truth's definitions are self-consistent, not contradictory. Correspondence asserts truth is consistent with physical reality.
Other standards of truth are derived from social concepts.
The epistemics of social ______ are complicated; however, the standards of truth are easy to identify: Authority and Consensus. Authority asserts some individual determines truth. Consensus asserts the collective determines truth.
A consensus of authorities asserts some particular collection of individuals determines truth.

It's required in a-priori arguments. It's annoyingly ineffable, and no description is technically correct. Martin Heidegger famously stated "The nothing itself nothings." 3.1.2: *Existence* is essentially the idea that concepts exist. It's required in a-priori arguments. 3.1.3: Distinction is essentially the differences between concepts. It allows you to define variables and relations in mathematics. 3.2: Correspondence derives from the a-priori fundemntal of experience. 3.2.1: Experience is the immutable existence of a physical reality. Also known as the emperical. 3.2.2: This allows you to asign emperical measures to mathematical variables. 3.3: Consensus & Authority derive from complex social relations. 3.3.1: They are extremely displaced from any a-priori fundementals.
